Thanks @liat-grozovik, Yes, it could be taken to 201911 and 202012 branches.
202012 cherry-pick is not clean. Please submit another PR on 202012 branch.

@tahmed-dev - What is the PR for 202012 ? Thanks!

> @tahmed-dev - What is the PR for 202012 ? Thanks!

[PR:1651](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-utilities/pull/1651) port this one to 202012. @dprital I am curious what this PR is blocking? If it blocking test code, I strongly believe the test code has to adapt and we don't need this PR in production.
@tahmed-dev , is this a bug fix? just curious, why is it required for 201911?

> @tahmed-dev , is this a bug fix? just curious, why is it required for 201911?

This is no bug here. the unsorted file was an artifact of removing `natsort` from config engine which in turn got removed from 201911 for fast reboot time enhancement.

There is no loss of functionality for master, 202012 or 201911. The issue that was created did not provide details why this is an issue. Removing 201911 label.

> > @tahmed-dev , is this a bug fix? just curious, why is it required for 201911?
> 
> This is no bug here. the unsorted file was an artifact of removing `natsort` from config engine which in turn got removed from 201911 for fast reboot time enhancement.
> 
> There is no loss of functionality for master, 202012 or 201911. The issue that was created did not provide details why this is an issue. Removing 201911 label.

Thanks Tamer
Thanks @arlakshm, LGTM!

> Formatting and alignment of code blocks in rendered Command-Reference.md appear incorrect. Formatting could be due to spaces preceding triple backticks. Please fix.

Thanks for catching it!
I have fixed it in the latest commit just now.
Code changes looks Okay. Please merge this one.
@yxieca , @abdosi  could you please merge
@monipko can you elaborate why this change is not needed in master branch? Was there a cherry-pick error caused this issue?

@yxieca This change is present in master branch (PR - https://github.com/Azure/sonic-utilities/pull/1383).
Is the issue fixed for master branch as well?
@neethajohn can you please review? this one is blocking us from moving forward with another fix we need on master.
Could you please add a unit test for `default` ?

> Could you please add a unit test for `default` ?

Done, please review the PR and merge if changes look good.
@theasianpianist: Please add labels as appropriate if this should be cherry-picked into release branches.
@robocoder99 can you please check the dependency in the comment? we need to have the public PR.
No dependency, this PR will safely handle if the data is not present in STATE_DB (it will be shown as blank if the PSU is present and it will show as N/A if it is not)

There is an example in the command reference for `show platform psustatus` that is currently shown as:

```
admin@sonic:~$ show platform psustatus
PSU    Status
-----  --------
PSU 1  OK
PSU 2  OK
```

I can add an update to this PR.

This pull request **introduces 1 alert** when merging 87d9861b75ddbe44d1ead19f939c57f8a88143bc into c166f66827157f8e442e2176ce3efe166a5f6b5e - [view on LGTM.com](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/Azure/sonic-utilities/rev/pr-a004d8c48ff5d0a9574fa945e73bf33a6d50dc19)

**new alerts:**

* 1 for Unused import

> Please remove unused import per LGTM

The unused import is for mock purpose:
```python
import mock_tables.dbconnector
```

> > Please remove unused import per LGTM
> 
> The unused import is for mock purpose:
> 
> ```python
> import mock_tables.dbconnector
> ```

Ah, yeah. That's annoying. We need to find a better way to do this (maybe using `mock.patch`?). So in the meantime this is OK. However, I think we should change this to align with Python 3's explicit relative import syntax: `from .mock_tables import dbconnector`

When I change it to relative import, I got error:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/sonic/src/sonic-utilities/scripts/portconfig", line 36, in <module>
    from .mock_tables import dbconnector
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named '__main__.mock_tables'; '__main__' is not a package
```

> c/sonic-utilities/scripts/portconfig", line 36, in <module>
>     from .mock_tables import dbconnector

Ah, right. Because this is in `portconfig`, not in a test file. Eventually we need to eliminate this `if os.environ["UTILITIES_UNIT_TESTING"] == "1":` check from the source files, and move all of this logic into the test files. I've begun doing it in a few places. For now this is OK.

This PR contains the same fix that is already in Azure/sonic-utilities#1566.
Azure/sonic-utilities#1566 needs to be cherry-picked to 202012 but this one doesn't.
So I suggest merging Azure/sonic-utilities#1566 first.

Here, the user is expected to run `route update` after every reboot?

@prsunny 
I don't think so, user shouldn't run this command manually after reboot. But I really don't know where this update function can be called, because it should be executed after the RIFs are generated, and running it in the startup script shouldn't work.

> @prsunny
> I don't think so, user shouldn't run this command manually after reboot. But I really don't know where this update function can be called, because it should be executed after the RIFs are generated, and running it in the startup script shouldn't work.

ok, so how is it expected to be restored from config_db after reboot?

> > @prsunny
> > I don't think so, user shouldn't run this command manually after reboot. But I really don't know where this update function can be called, because it should be executed after the RIFs are generated, and running it in the startup script shouldn't work.
> 
> ok, so how is it expected to be restored from config_db after reboot?

I'm not sure, but maybe the update can be triggered using crontab or along with running the bgp container.
Can you add unit-tests as well?

Why is the schema showing nexthop in key?
```
       "1.2.3.4/32|30.0.0.5": {
            "nexthop": "30.0.0.5",
            "prefix": "1.2.3.4/32"
        },
```

And also why do we need prefix in the value field? It's already part of the key... 
For static route table the scheme is prefix as key and nexthop as field as the simplest case..
we already have frrcfgd monitoring config db, so the part of programming frr cfg is not necessary as long as config_db is updated, isn't it?

@prsunny @caizhenghui-juniper
I updated the record name with a prefix as the key and nexthop as the value, and also added base UT. But I cannot find frrcfgd in the repositories, can you tell me where it is?

Hi, Dmytro,

Here it is: https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/tree/master/src/sonic-frr-mgmt-framework/frrcfgd
One more issue: in swss, we do require VRF name conforms with prefix Vrf, so please correct that in VRF test case accordingly. Small problem 😊
And the schema defined in frrcfgd for vrf is using vrf_name instead of vrf.
Plus, are you still setting prefix as field? At line 3248?

Thanks

Zhenghui

and can you put support for ECMP too? With more than 1 next hops for the static routes?

I'm not sure if this is a bug or not, but after reboot, the frr daemon does not start with the system, and also after manual start, the daemon sees a static route, but does not add it to frr cfg

**Before reboot**
```
sudo config route add prefix 1.2.3.4/32 nexthop 30.0.0.5
```
```
"STATIC_ROUTE": {
	"1.2.3.4/32": {
		"nexthop": "30.0.0.5"
	}
}


admin@sonic:~$ redis-cli -n 4 keys "*" | grep STATIC_ROUTE
STATIC_ROUTE|1.2.3.4/32
admin@sonic:~$ redis-cli -n 4 hgetall "STATIC_ROUTE|1.2.3.4/32"
1) "nexthop"
2) "30.0.0.5"
```
```
admin@sonic:~$ show ip route
Codes: K - kernel route, C - connected, S - static, R - RIP,
       O - OSPF, I - IS-IS, B - BGP, E - EIGRP, N - NHRP,
       T - Table, v - VNC, V - VNC-Direct, A - Babel, D - SHARP,
       F - PBR, f - OpenFabric,
       > - selected route, * - FIB route, q - queued, r - rejected, b - backup

S>* 0.0.0.0/0 [200/0] via 192.168.111.3, eth0, weight 1, 00:05:24
S>  1.2.3.4/32 [1/0] via 30.0.0.7 (recursive), weight 1, 00:00:06
C>* 10.1.0.1/32 is directly connected, Loopback0, 00:05:07
C>* 192.168.111.0/24 is directly connected, eth0, 00:05:25
```

**After reboot**

Syslog
```
May  7 21:22:18.776046 sonic DEBUG bgp#/frrcfgd: entering BGP configuration daemon
May  7 21:22:18.780913 sonic DEBUG bgp#/frrcfgd: send initial enable command to bgpd

May  7 21:22:18.784148 sonic DEBUG bgp#/frrcfgd: send initial enable command to ospfd
May  7 21:22:18.784148 sonic DEBUG bgp#/frrcfgd: send initial enable command to pimd
May  7 21:22:18.810021 sonic DEBUG bgp#/frrcfgd: entering VTYSH proxy thread

May  7 21:22:18.899398 sonic DEBUG bgp#/frrcfgd: Init Cached DB data
May  7 21:22:19.926529 sonic DEBUG bgp#/frrcfgd:   STATIC_ROUTE&&1.2.3.4/32 : {'nexthop': '30.0.0.5'}
```
```
admin@sonic:~$ show ip route
Codes: K - kernel route, C - connected, S - static, R - RIP,
       O - OSPF, I - IS-IS, B - BGP, E - EIGRP, N - NHRP,
       T - Table, v - VNC, V - VNC-Direct, A - Babel, D - SHARP,
       F - PBR, f - OpenFabric,
       > - selected route, * - FIB route, q - queued, r - rejected, b - backup

S>* 0.0.0.0/0 [200/0] via 192.168.111.3, eth0, weight 1, 00:05:24
C>* 10.1.0.1/32 is directly connected, Loopback0, 00:05:07
C>* 192.168.111.0/24 is directly connected, eth0, 00:05:25
```
And if I try to change the nexthop on this entry, staticd crashes because it has no previous entry
```
sudo config route add prefix 1.2.3.4/32 nexthop 30.0.0.5
```
```
May  7 21:09:27.483443 sonic DEBUG bgp#/frrcfgd: ----------------------------------

Please update CLI command reference [document ](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-utilities/blob/master/doc/Command-Reference.md)

> I see that this PR is missing ecmp handling. In the existing code, by calling vtysh, it does handle ECMP. My suggestion is, when user configure the same route prefix with a different nexthop, it should modify the STATIC_ROUTE DB entry instead of overwriting thus supporting ECMP (similar to vtysh). @shi-su, this should be handled by bgpcfgd.

Yes, the STATIC_ROUTE DB entry needs to be updated when nexthop changes. The bgpcfgd should be able to know the changes and only apply the differences for the same route prefix.

I found that the daemon cannot create direct routes to interfaces.

When I tried to set it up this way:
```
"10.10.10.0/24": {
	"nexthop": "Ethernet0"
}
```
Daemon returns error: ip in nexthop is invalid

Otherwise:
```
"10.10.10.0/24": {
	"ifname": "Ethernet0"
}
```
Daemon returns error: nexthop ip not found

> I found that the daemon cannot create direct routes to interfaces.
> 
> When I tried to set it up this way:
> 
> ```
> "10.10.10.0/24": {
> 	"nexthop": "Ethernet0"
> }
> ```
> 
> Daemon returns error: ip in nexthop is invalid
> 
> Otherwise:
> 
> ```
> "10.10.10.0/24": {
> 	"ifname": "Ethernet0"
> }
> ```
> 
> Daemon returns error: nexthop ip not found

The second case is valid and should be handled by bgpcfgd. @shi-su

> > I found that the daemon cannot create direct routes to interfaces.
> > When I tried to set it up this way:
> > ```
> > "10.10.10.0/24": {
> > 	"nexthop": "Ethernet0"
> > }
> > ```
> > 
> > 
> > Daemon returns error: ip in nexthop is invalid
> > Otherwise:
> > ```
> > "10.10.10.0/24": {
> > 	"ifname": "Ethernet0"
> > }
> > ```
> > 
> > 
> > Daemon returns error: nexthop ip not found
> 
> The second case is valid and should be handled by bgpcfgd. @shi-su

bgpcfgd is actually handling the second case:
```
admin@vlab-01:~$ sudo sonic-cfggen -a '{"STATIC_ROUTE":{"10.27.0.0/24": {"ifname": "Ethernet0"}}}' --write-to-db
admin@vlab-01:~$ show ip route 10.27.0.1
Routing entry for 10.27.0.0/24
  Known via "static", distance 1, metric 0
  Last update 00:00:07 ago
    directly connected, Ethernet0 inactive, weight 1
```
@shi-su , could you please review/sign-off?
@prsunny - Can you please add the tag "Required to 202012" ?
Is this already available in the prebuilt sonic-aboot-broadcom.swi ? If not, then how to configure (and persist across reboots) static routes?

Two questions:

1. What about backporting to the 202012 branch?
2. How can we be certain there are no broken changes with future versions? That was the whole reason for pinning the versions down -- to prevent newer versions getting installed and potentially breaking things.

---
In reply to: [808638168](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-utilities/pull/1530#issuecomment-808638168) [](http://example.com/codeflow?ancestors=808638168)

1. I added 'request' label for old branch.
2. When that happens, we could add new requirement rule to enforce the dependency. On the other hand, pinning down is too conservative, and we need to make sure the host environment or docker already installed the required version, otherwise, there will be upgrade/downgrade, which is confusing.


---
In reply to: [808638168](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-utilities/pull/1530#issuecomment-808638168) [](http://example.com/codeflow?ancestors=808638168,808638168)
